answers.text:
Hello Jeffrey,
In answering this question, I'd like to note that data security breaches are fraught with legal issues and it is important to consult with a lawyer when developing a response plan.  This being said, I have found some things that might interest you.
First is an article from December's issue of Public Management.  It generally outlines the need for data protection and ways to prepare for attacks and breaches:
http://webapps.icma.org/pm/9411/public/feature2.cfm?title=Defending%20against%20Technology%E2%80%99s%20Dark%20Side%20&subtitle=Yes%2C%20a%20data%20breach%20could%20happen%20in%20your%20community&author=Kirstin%20Simonson
The American Bar Association has put out a Model Data Security Breach Preparedness Guide, available here:
http://www.americanbar.org/content/dam/aba/administrative/litigation/materials/sac_2012/22-15_intro_to_data_security_breach_preparedness.authcheckdam.pdf
Finally, a company called Debix has produced an Incident Response Workbook to help your organization put together an Incidence Response Plan.  Section 6 includes a sample document which might serve as a guide for which information is important to gather in the aftermath of an incident:
https://www.diskagent.com/resources/Data_Breach_Incident_Response_Workbook_by_Debix.pdf
I hope this helps you.
Gabe Brehm
Knowledge Network Intern
ICMA
